Never before has Twitter played such a prominent role in an election. If Clinton or Trump wants to say something, react to news in real time -- even if it's at 3 a.m. -- they don't need to coordinate a press conference. They just need to tap that little blue bird. And in a blink of an eye, they’ve reached millions.

The Huffington Post wanted to find out more about the people who follow the candidates. We hoped their 160-character bios might reveal a thing or two about political identity. And so we downloaded the Twitter bios for people who follow either Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump. That ended up being about 8 million, 160-character tiny self-portraits. A big caveat: a Trump or Clinton follower does not a Trump or Clinton voter make. In other words, this is not a scientific data set, and we’re not here to make big new proclamations about the American Voter. Mostly we’re just trying to scratch the itch of curiosity. Who is more likely to be a follower of Trump? Of Clinton?

So, what to make of all of this?

In the 1990s a linguist at the University of California Berkeley named George Lakoff wanted to know why certain beliefs are often grouped together. For example, what does being a pro-life Christian have to do with owning guns? Or patriotism and nationalism? Or small government?

Here’s what Lakoff came up with: people’s politics line up with how they view family. Whereas progressives believe in what Lakoff calls the “The Nurturant Parent” family, conservatives believe in the “Strict Father.”

“Father knows best,” Lakoff wrote in a blog post for The Huffington Post about the Strict Father model. “He knows right from wrong and has the ultimate authority to make sure his children and his spouse do what he says, which is taken to be what is right.”

And in the strict father worldview, there’s a deep respect for social hierarchies in which “those who have traditionally dominated should dominate,” Lakoff wrote. God is above man. Man above nature. Rich above the poor. Western culture above other cultures. Christians above non-Christians. And America above other countries.
In other words, it’s why conservatives are seemingly more religious and nationalistic.

Trump, Lakoff says, represents the ultimate strict father. Problems are dealt with simply, directly, and without nuance. That’s why it’s easy for Trump to say, “Build a wall” as a solution for stopping immigrants. Or the cure for gun violence is to arm the victim. Terrorism? Ban Muslims and destroy ISIS. Easy-peasy-lemon-squeezy.

In the Nurturant Parent model, there aren’t as strict rules or hierarchies. Discipline isn’t emphasized as much as respect and compassion. That’s why progressives, like Clinton, are often derided as “feel-good” or “bleeding heart” liberals. They want to join the Peace Corps. They want to stand up for human rights. It’s not the refugee’s fault that they’re a refugee. It’s not the homeless person’s fault that their homeless. Drug addiction isn’t a lapse in will -- it’s a treatable illness.

Lakoff’s model makes sense when looking at We The Tweeple. Here we have 8 million portraits of political people, collectively falling into models of mother and models of father, democrats or republicans, all followers of a democracy that’s here because of a deep human need for freedom. Freedom of will. Freedom of the pursuit of happiness. Freedom to describe yourself however you like.
